{{Use Canadian English|date=August 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} [[File:Winnipeg satellite image NASA.jpg|thumb|Satellite image of Winnipeg]] [[File:Winnipeg skyline from 55 Nassau.jpg|thumb|Winnipeg's skyline]] [[Winnipeg]] lies at the bottom of the [[Red River Valley]], a low-lying flood plain with an extremely flat topography.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gsc.nrcan.gc.ca/floods/redriver/geomorphology_e.php |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110604201210/http://gsc.nrcan.gc.ca/floods/redriver/geomorphology_e.php |archivedate=4 June 2011 |title=Geomorphology of the Red River|publisher=Natural Resources Canada|accessdate=9 May 2012}}</ref> This valley was formed by the ancient glacial Lake Agassiz which has rich deposits of black soil. Winnipeg is on the eastern edge of the [[Canadian Prairies]] in [[Western Canada]]; it is known as the 'Gateway to the West'. It is relatively close to many large [[Canadian Shield]] lakes and parks, as well as [[Lake Winnipeg]] ([[List of lakes by area|the Earth's 11th largest freshwater lake]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ilec.or.jp/database/nam/nam-08.html |title=Lake Winnipeg |author=World Lake Database |accessdate=5 January 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070210173421/http://www.ilec.or.jp/database/nam/nam-08.html |archivedate=10 February 2007 |df=dmy }}</ref> Winnipeg is bordered by [[tallgrass prairie]] to the west and south and the [[aspen parkland]] to the northeast.
Winnipeg is fairly isolated in that the closest city with equal or greater population is [[Minneapolis–Saint Paul]], Minnesota (metro population of 3,317,308), which is 735 km (457 miles) southeast from the city. According to the [[Census geographic units of Canada]], the city has a total area of {{convert|464.01|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}} and an elevation of 240 m (786 ft).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://winnipeg.ca/census/includes/Geographies.stm|title=City of Winnipeg Community Profile: Overview|publisher=Government of Manitoba|accessdate=16 July 2009}}</ref>
The city has a [[humid continental climate]] with wide temperature contrasts between winter and summer, and greater precipitation in summer. Mean January temperature is {{convert|-16.4|C|F}}, and mean July temperature is {{convert|19.7|C|F}}. Average annual precipitation is {{convert|521.1|mm|abbr=on|2}}; snow falls on 53 days and lies on 132 days in an average year.
Winnipeg has three major rivers: the [[Red River of the North|Red River]], the [[Assiniboine River]], and the [[Seine River (Manitoba)|Seine River]]. The Red River is a [[Canadian Heritage Rivers System|Canadian heritage river]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.riverswest.ca/index.cfm?pageID=4 |title=Projects and Progress |publisher=Rivers West |accessdate=16 July 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090704030441/http://www.riverswest.ca/index.cfm?pageID=4 |archivedate=4 July 2009 |df=dmy }}</ref> Because of Winnipeg's extremely flat topography and substantial snowfall, Winnipeg is subject to severe flooding. The Red River reached its greatest flood height in 1826. The [[Red River Floodway]] protects the city from flooding.
==Cityscape== [[File:Portage Ave. Winnipeg.jpg|thumb|Downtown Winnipeg Portage Avenue]] {{further information|List of Winnipeg neighbourhoods|List of tallest buildings in Winnipeg}} According to the [[Canada 2001 Census|2001 Census]], there are 230 neighbourhoods in Winnipeg.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.statcan.gc.ca/pub/85-561-m/2004004/4144286-eng.htm#box|title=Methodology|date=16 September 2004|publisher=Statistics Canada|accessdate=18 January 2010}}</ref> [[Downtown Winnipeg]], the city's economic core, is centred on the intersection of [[Portage and Main|Portage Avenue and Main Street]] (reputed to be one of the windiest in Canada).<ref>{{cite book|last=Colombo|first=John Robert|title=Canadian literary landmarks|publisher=Dundurn Press Ltd.|year=1984}}</ref> Downtown Winnipeg covers an area of about one square mile (2.5 km<sup>2</sup>) and is the fastest growing high-income neighbourhood in the city.{{citation needed|reason=Dubious claim without citation|date=November 2014}} More than 72,000 people work downtown, and over 40,000 students attend classes at its universities and colleges.{{citation needed|reason=Claim without citation|date=November 2014}} The past few decades have seen downtown undergo major revitalization efforts; since 1999, over [[C$]]1.2 billion has been invested.{{citation needed|reason=Claim without citation|date=November 2014}}
In Winnipeg, there are 10 buildings that stand taller than {{convert|85|m|ft|abbr=on|adj=on|0}}. The tallest building in the city is the newer 33-[[storey]], {{convert|128|m|ft|abbr=on|adj=on|0}} [[201 Portage]].<ref name="Canwest">{{Cite web |title=Canwest Place |url=http://skyscraperpage.com/cities/?buildingID=4936 |publisher=Skyscraperpage |accessdate=4 March 2011}}</ref> The second tallest building in the city is the [[Richardson Building (Winnipeg)|Richardson Building]], standing at {{convert|124|m|ft|abbr=on|0}} tall with 34 storeys.<ref name="Richardson Building">{{Cite web |title=Richardson Building |url=http://skyscraperpage.com/cities/?buildingID=6184 |publisher=Skyscraperpage |accessdate=4 March 2011}}</ref>
[[File:Downtown Winnipeg and the Exchange District, Manitoba, Canada - 20110530.jpg|thumb|200px|upright|The [[Exchange District]].]] Downtown Winnipeg's [[Exchange District]] is named after the area's original grain exchange from 1880 to 1913.<ref name="BIZ">{{cite web|url=http://www.downtownwinnipegbiz.com/resource/file/DBIZ_Trends_2010.pdf |title=downtownwinnipegbiz Trends 2010 |date=8 July 2010 |publisher=Downtown Winnipeg BIZ |accessdate=21 July 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140111075234/http://www.downtownwinnipegbiz.com/resource/file/DBIZ_Trends_2010.pdf |archivedate=11 January 2014 |df=dmy }}</ref> The 30-block district received National Historic Site of Canada status in 1997; it includes North America's most extensive collection of early 20th-century [[terracotta]] and cut stone architecture, 62 of downtown Winnipeg's 86 heritage structures,<ref name="BIZ"/> [[Stephen Juba]] Park, and Old Market Square, home to [[Jazz Winnipeg Festival|Winnipeg Jazz]] and [[Winnipeg Fringe Theatre Festival|Fringe Festivals]].<ref name="BIZ"/> Other major downtown areas include [[The Forks, Winnipeg|The Forks]], [[Central Park (Winnipeg)|Central Park]], Broadway-Assiniboine and [[Chinatown, Winnipeg|Chinatown]]. Many of Downtown Winnipeg's major buildings are linked with the [[Winnipeg Walkway]] skywalk.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.winnipeg.ca/ppd/planning/pdf_folder/dwntwnprofile.pdf|title=Downtown Winnipeg Profile|publisher=City of Winnipeg|accessdate=16 July 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928014925/http://www.winnipeg.ca/ppd/planning/pdf_folder/dwntwnprofile.pdf|archivedate=28 September 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Various residential neighbourhoods surround downtown in all directions, but expansion is greatest to the south and west, and has tended to follow the course of the two major rivers. The urbanized area in Winnipeg is about {{convert|25|km|mi|abbr=on}} from east to west and {{convert|20|km|mi|abbr=on}} from north to south, although several areas remain underdeveloped. The largest park in the city, [[Assiniboine Park]] next to the affluent neighbourhood of [[Tuxedo, Winnipeg|Tuxedo]], houses the [[Assiniboine Park Zoo]] and the [[Leo Mol]] Sculpture Garden, Other large city parks include [[Kildonan Park]], [[St. Vital Park]], and Fort Whyte Centre. The major commercial areas in the city are [[Polo Park]] (West End and St. James), Kildonan Crossing (Transcona and East Kildonan), South St. Vital, Garden City (West Kildonan) and the Corydon strip.
[[File:Osborne Village2.jpg|thumb|left|[[Osborne Village]]]] [[Osborne Village]] is Winnipeg's most densely populated neighbourhood,<ref name="Where.ca">{{cite web|title=Neighbourhoods: The Village Pilgrimage |url=http://www.where.ca/Winnipeg/article_feature.cfm?listing_id=14 |publisher=Where.ca |accessdate=23 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110807034934/http://www.where.ca/winnipeg/article_feature.cfm?listing_id=14 |archivedate=7 August 2011 |df=dmy }}</ref> as well as the second most densely populated neighbourhood in Western Canada.<ref>City of Winnipeg Osborne Village neighbourhood Plan http://winnipeg.ca/clkdmis/documents/c/2006/a6621/pd%2009%2019%20no.%2015%20att.pdf</ref> It was voted the Best Place to Live in Uptown Magazine's 2008 Best of List.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.uptownmag.com/2008-05-15/page2270.aspx |title=BEST OF WINNIPEG 2008!}}</ref> Osborne Village is a complex urban community with a rich heritage and diverse built forms. It’s appreciated as a desirable location in which to live, work, and play. As such, it continues to experience development interest. Popular annual events include the Canada Day Festival. Osborne Village is home to one of Winnipeg's most vibrant collection of stores and restaurants with over 175 businesses calling Osborne Village home.
[[Little Italy, Winnipeg|Little Italy]] is a vibrant Italian district. Located on [[Corydon Avenue]], between [[Winnipeg Route 70|Stafford Street]] in the west, and [[Winnipeg Route 42|Pembina Highway]] in the east it is home to many boutiques and some of the city's finest restaurants and [[Gelato]].{{citation needed|reason=Claim without citation|date=November 2014}}
[[Saint Boniface, Manitoba|Saint Boniface]] is the centre of much of the [[Franco-Manitoban]] community. It features such landmarks as the Cathédrale de Saint Boniface (St. Boniface Cathedral), Boulevard Provencher, the Provencher Bridge, Esplanade Riel, St. Boniface Hospital, the Collège universitaire de Saint-Boniface and the Royal Canadian Mint. It covers the southeast part of the city and has a population of 65,000.
===Roadways and addresses=== {{refimprove section|date=January 2014}} The city uses the [[grid plan]] but there are several different grids in place, as the city was originally thirteen separate municipalities and each developed under different circumstances and under different rules. Although it is common for roadways running north-south to be called "streets" and those running east-west to be called "avenues", the practice is far from universal, and few roadways run in a precise cardinal direction; an "east-west" road may run at a 45 degree angle from true east-west. Attempts in the early 20th century to bring order to the system by giving numerical names to the streets failed; all roadways in the city have proper names, some of which are repeated. (There is, for instance, a Wellington Crescent in River Heights and a Wellington Avenue in the West End, and a Killarney Avenue in Fort Garry and a Killarney Street in St. Vital.)
There is also no universal address numbering system in place. Address numbers usually increase as the distance from either the Red or Assiniboine rivers increases, but this is by no means uniform, even within a specific district. These peculiarities can cause serious problems for newcomers and visitors, especially in the older areas of the city, and may even affect postal and other deliveries.
Many of the main thoroughfares in Winnipeg are wide due to the spring soil conditions and the historical use of the [[Red River ox cart]] which created wide ruts in the (then) muddy roads. Portage Avenue has four lanes of traffic in each direction plus a central boulevard for much of its run through Winnipeg. Few thoroughfares, however, are as wide as the freeways seen in other Canadian cities (such as the 401 in Toronto or [[Deerfoot Trail]] in Calgary). Residential streets are commonly significantly narrower than streets in other Western Canadian cities, so narrow that parking is only possible on one side of the street.
==Climate== Winnipeg lies in the middle of the North American continent on a low-lying, flat plain. Due to its location in the [[Canadian Prairies]], and its distance from both mountains and oceans, it has an extreme [[humid continental climate]] ([[Köppen climate classification|Köppen]] ''Dfb'',<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hydrol-earth-syst-sci.net/11/1633/2007/hess-11-1633-2007.pdf |title=Updated world map of the Köppen-Geiger climate classification |publisher=[[University of Melbourne]] |accessdate=8 March 2011 }}</ref> USDA [[Hardiness zone|Plant Hardiness Zone]] 2b),<ref name="Plant Hardiness Zones">{{cite web|url=http://atlas.nrcan.gc.ca/site/english/maps/environment/forest/forestcanada/planthardi|title=The Atlas of Canada|publisher=Natural Resources Canada|accessdate=2 April 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100327150913/http://atlas.nrcan.gc.ca/site/english/maps/environment/forest/forestcanada/planthardi|archivedate=27 March 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref> in that there are great differences between summer and winter temperatures. The openness of the prairies leaves Winnipeg exposed to numerous weather systems including blizzards and cold [[Arctic]] [[High-pressure area|high pressure systems]], known as the [[polar high]]. Winnipeg has four distinct seasons, with short transitional periods between winter and summer.
The city averages {{convert|521.1|mm|abbr=on|2}} of precipitation per year, although this can vary greatly from year to year.<ref name="CCN"/>
{{Winnipeg weatherbox}}
Climate data is also available for downtown Winnipeg, with a weather station located at [[The Forks, Winnipeg|The Forks]]. This data demonstrates the [[urban heat island effect]] cities have on moderating temperatures compared to airport weather stations.
{{Weather box/concise_C |location = Winnipeg (The Forks), Manitoba (1999-2017) |source = [[Environment Canada]]<ref>"[http://climate.weather.gc.ca/climateData/dailydata_e.html?StationID=28051 Winnipeg The Forks]{{Failed verification|date=May 2016}} {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140221233457/http://climate.weather.gc.ca/climateData/dailydata_e.html?StationID=28051 |date=21 February 2014 }}", Environment Canada, 2014.</ref> |-10.0|-8.2|0.1|10.6|17.5|23.1|26.6|25.4|20.2|11.0|1.4|-7.8<!--highs--> |-17.9|-16.9|-9.2|0.1|6.6|13.0|16.4|14.9|9.9|2.8|-5.7|-15.0<!--lows--> }}
===Winter=== [[File:River River Curling.jpg|thumb|[[Curling rink]] on the [[Red River of the North|Red River]] at [[The Forks, Winnipeg|The Forks]]]] Typical winter phenomena include the [[Thaw (weather)|bonspiel (January) thaw]], [[ice fog]], and the [[aurora borealis]]. The city is virtually assured of having a [[White Christmas (weather)|white Christmas]] as there is only one 25 December on record in the last century where there was no snow on the ground. Out of Canada's 100 largest cities, Winnipeg's winter is the tenth coldest with an average low of {{convert|-20.2|C}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.climate.weatheroffice.gc.ca/winners/categorydata_e.html?SelectedCategory=2&submit=Submit |title=Coldest winter |publisher=Environment Canada |accessdate=22 December 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130120050239/http://www.climate.weatheroffice.gc.ca/winners/categorydata_e.html?SelectedCategory=2&submit=Submit |archivedate=20 January 2013 |df=dmy }}</ref> From December through February the maximum daily temperature exceeds {{convert|0|C|0}}, on average, for only 10 days and the minimum daily temperature falls below {{convert|-20|C|0}} on 49 days.
===Summer=== [[File:Winnipeg summer climate graph.jpg|thumb|200px|Winnipeg mid-summer climate chart.]] Summers are typically warm and generally not overly humid, with average humidity levels around 50% from June to August. Occasionally, [[humidex]] readings exceed 40. The trees will usually be in full bloom by late May and do not lose their leaves until early October. Winnipeg's growing season lasts from 25 May to 22 September;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almanac.com/content/frost-chart-canada|title=Frost Chart for Canada|year=2012|publisher=The Old Farmers Almanac|accessdate=15 September 2012}}</ref> and temperatures frequently hover in the mid to high twenties Celsius (77F to 86F). The city frequently gets thunderstorms during the summer, averaging 27 per season.<ref name="Most thunderstorm days">{{cite web|url=http://www.climate.weatheroffice.gc.ca/winners/categorydata_e.html?SelectedCategory=35&submit=Submit |title=Most thunderstorm days |publisher=Environment Canada |accessdate=2012-10-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130120050234/http://www.climate.weatheroffice.gc.ca/winners/categorydata_e.html?SelectedCategory=35&submit=Submit |archivedate=20 January 2013 |df=dmy }}</ref> The city can occasionally have short blasts of hot weather like on 23 August 2011 the temperature reached {{convert|37.2|C|0}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.climate.weatheroffice.gc.ca/climateData/dailydata_e.html?timeframe=2&Prov=MAN&StationID=47407&dlyRange=2008-07-03%7C2012-10-02&Year=2011&Month=8&Day=01 |title=Daily Data Report for August 2011 |publisher=Environment Canada |accessdate=3 October 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130120050309/http://www.climate.weatheroffice.gc.ca/climateData/dailydata_e.html?timeframe=2&Prov=MAN&StationID=47407&dlyRange=2008-07-03%7C2012-10-02&Year=2011&Month=8&Day=01 |archivedate=20 January 2013 |df=dmy }}</ref> The temperature reaches at or above {{convert|30|C|0}} 14 times a year, which is ranked the 16th highest in Canada, just above [[Toronto|Toronto, Ontario]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.climate.weatheroffice.gc.ca/winners/categorydata_e.html?SelectedCategory=10&submit=Submit |title=Most hot days (30°C or above) |publisher=Environment Canada |accessdate=4 January 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130120050351/http://www.climate.weatheroffice.gc.ca/winners/categorydata_e.html?SelectedCategory=10&submit=Submit |archivedate=20 January 2013 |df=dmy }}</ref> The highest temperature ever recorded in Winnipeg (since commencement of record-keeping in 1873) was {{convert|42.2|C|0}} on 11 July 1936;<ref name="Daily Data Report for July 1936">{{cite web |url=http://www.climate.weatheroffice.ec.gc.ca/climateData/dailydata_e.html?timeframe=2&Prov=CA&StationID=3703&Year=1936&Month=7&Day=29 |archive-url=https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20130120050236/http://www.climate.weatheroffice.ec.gc.ca/climateData/dailydata_e.html?timeframe=2&Prov=CA&StationID=3703&Year=1936&Month=7&Day=29 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=20 January 2013 |title=Daily Data Report for July 1936 |publisher=Environment Canada |accessdate=31 July 2009 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> and the hottest temperature recorded in the past 25 years was {{convert|38.7|C|0}} on 6 August 1988 and again on 1 August 1989. The highest humidex reading was 48 on 25 July 2007.<ref name="humidex">{{cite web|url=http://web2.gov.mb.ca/agriculture/mwvr/ |title=Manitoba Weekly Vegetable Report |author=Government of Manitoba |accessdate=2 September 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080821151831/http://web2.gov.mb.ca/agriculture/mwvr/ |archivedate=21 August 2008 |df=dmy }}</ref>
===Spring and autumn=== [[File:Forks Riverwalk.jpg|thumb|upright|Assiniboine River walkway near [[The Forks, Winnipeg|The Forks]] in fall]] The weather during these seasons is highly variable, and rapidly changing. For example, temperatures in Winnipeg in April have ranged from {{convert|-6.3|C|0}} to {{convert|34.3|C|0}}, and in October from {{convert|-6|C|0}} to {{convert|30.5|C|0}}. The city often receives an [[Indian summer]], when summer weather returns briefly after the first frosts, usually in late September or sometimes October. Some Septembers can have gorgeous weather, like in September 2009 Winnipeg only saw 4 days with daytime highs below 20.0C (68.0F) at the Forks weather station.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.climate.weatheroffice.gc.ca/climateData/dailydata_e.html?timeframe=2&Prov=MAN&StationID=28051&dlyRange=1999-11-01&Month=9&Day=14&Year=2009 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20121216032721/http://www.climate.weatheroffice.gc.ca/climateData/dailydata_e.html?timeframe=2&Prov=MAN&StationID=28051&dlyRange=1999-11-01&Month=9&Day=14&Year=2009 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=16 December 2012 |title=Daily Data Report for September 2009 |publisher=Environment Canada |accessdate=15 September 2012 }}</ref>
===Sunshine=== Winnipeg is one of Canada's sunniest cities, and the weather in all seasons is characterized by an abundance of sunshine. In July and August combined, Winnipeg has 60 out of 62 days with measurable sunshine; and has an annual average of 306 days a year with measurable sunshine.<ref name="Canadian Climate Normals 1971-2000" /> November is the least sunny month while July and August are the most sunny months.<ref name="Canadian Climate Normals 1971-2000"/> Winnipeg is ranked second for Canada's clearest skies year-round, sixth sunniest city year-round, and second for sunniest city in Canada in spring and winter.<ref name="CCN">{{cite web|url=http://www.climate.weatheroffice.gc.ca/winners/citydata_e.html?SelectedCity=123&submit=Submit |accessdate=17 January 2012 |title=Winnipeg MB |publisher=Environment Canada |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130120050347/http://www.climate.weatheroffice.gc.ca/winners/citydata_e.html?SelectedCity=123&submit=Submit |archivedate=20 January 2013 |df=dmy }}</ref> Winnipeg is sunnier in the summer, spring, and winter than any Canadian city east of it.<ref name="Summer sunny days Weather Winners">{{cite web|url=http://climate.weatheroffice.gc.ca/winners/categorydata_e.html?SelectedCategory=43&submit=Submit |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130101032534/http://climate.weatheroffice.gc.ca/winners/categorydata_e.html?SelectedCategory=43&submit=Submit |dead-url=yes |archive-date=1 January 2013 |accessdate=8 September 2012 |title=Sunniest summer |publisher=Environment Canada }}</ref> Winnipeg has short daylight hours in the winter and long daylight hours in the summer. On the shortest day of the year (21 December) Winnipeg only has 8 hours and 5 minutes of daylight with the sun setting at 4:29pm and doesn't rise until 8:24am.<ref name="Sun, Moon and Seasons: Calculator">{{cite web | url=http://www.theweathernetwork.com/index.php?product=moonsun | title= Sun, Moon and Seasons: Calculator| publisher= The Weather Network | accessdate=25 December 2012}}</ref> On 21 June (the longest day of the year) Winnipeg has 16 hours and 21 minutes of daylight with twilight ending at 10:25pm and twilight starting at 4:35am.<ref name="Sun, Moon and Seasons: Calculator"/>
===Precipitation=== Winnipeg has moderate precipitation with {{convert|513.7|mm|abbr=on|2}} of precip per year.<ref name="CCN"/> There is measurable rainfall on 76.9 days throughout the year, and 54.7 days with snowfall.<ref name="CCN"/> Most of the precipitation occurs in the warmer months, with June being the wettest month and February being the driest. Droughts can take place in the region, however they do not happen as frequently as cities further west like Calgary or Swift Current. During the winter Winnipeg will get precipitation mostly in the form of snow, with 36 days of snow falling from December to February. Even in the winter there is occasional rainfall with 2.5 days on average of rainfall during December to February.<ref name="Canadian Climate Normals 1971-2000">{{cite web |url=http://www.climate.weatheroffice.gc.ca/climate_normals/results_e.html?stnID=3698&prov=&lang=e&dCode=1&dispBack=1&StationName=winnipeg_&SearchType=Contains&province=ALL&provBut=&month1=0&month2=12|title=Canadian Climate Normals 1971–2000 |publisher=Environment Canada |accessdate=5 January 2013 }}</ref> Other forms of winter precipitation include ice, sleet, and freezing rain. Snow cover usually lasts from November till March, about 132 days or 36% of the year;.<ref name="Longest snow cover season days">{{cite web|url=http://www.climate.weatheroffice.gc.ca/winners/categorydata_e.html?SelectedCategory=30&submit=Submit |title=Longest snow cover season (days) |publisher=Environment Canada |accessdate=22 December 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130120050314/http://www.climate.weatheroffice.gc.ca/winners/categorydata_e.html?SelectedCategory=30&submit=Submit |archivedate=20 January 2013 |df=dmy }}</ref> The city frequently gets thunderstorms during the summer, averaging 27 days a year with thunderstorms.<ref name="Most thunderstorm days"/>
===Wind=== Winnipeg has a reputation for being a windy city with the intersection of Portage and Main being called the windiest intersection in Canada;<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/sunday/toptencities/winnipeg.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071025010446/http://www.cbc.ca/sunday/toptencities/winnipeg.html|archivedate=25 October 2007|title=Winnipeg|year=2003|work=Top 10 Cities|publisher=CBC|accessdate=28 December 2009}}</ref> however, Winnipeg is only the 12th windiest city in Canada, just below Hamilton, Ontario.<ref name="Windiest location year-round">{{cite web|url=http://www.climate.weatheroffice.gc.ca/winners/categorydata_e.html?SelectedCategory=60&submit=Submit |archive-url=https://archive.is/20121216045102/http://www.climate.weatheroffice.gc.ca/winners/categorydata_e.html?SelectedCategory=60&submit=Submit |dead-url=yes |archive-date=16 December 2012 |accessdate=17 September 2012 |title=Windiest location year-round |publisher=Environment Canada }}</ref> The average annual wind speed is {{convert|16.9|km/h|abbr=on}}, predominantly from the south but the city has experienced wind gusts of up to {{convert|129|km/h|abbr=on}}.<ref name="CCN"/> April is the windiest month, and July the least windy. [[Tornado]]es do occur in the area, particularly in the spring and summer months, however they are not frequent.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://atlas.nrcan.gc.ca/site/english/maps/environment/naturalhazards/naturalhazards1999/majortornadoes/1 |title=Major Tornadoes |publisher=The Atlas of Canada |accessdate=18 September 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121006182414/http://atlas.nrcan.gc.ca/site/english/maps/environment/naturalhazards/naturalhazards1999/majortornadoes/1 |archivedate=6 October 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> A [[Fujita scale]] [[Elie, Manitoba tornado|F5]] tornado struck [[Elie, Manitoba|Elie]] (just {{convert|40|km|mi|abbr=on}} west of Winnipeg) in [[Tornadoes of 2007|2007]]; this was the strongest tornado ever recorded in Canada.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ec.gc.ca/default.asp?lang=En&n=714D9AAE-1&news=4B3DE57E-4967-4B09-98D6-EF974B32D6B5 |title=Canada's First Official F5 Tornado |date=18 September 2007 |publisher=Environment Canada |accessdate=16 July 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726210641/http://www.ec.gc.ca/default.asp?lang=En&n=714D9AAE-1&news=4B3DE57E-4967-4B09-98D6-EF974B32D6B5 |archivedate=26 July 2011 }}</ref>
==Flooding== {{further information|Red River Floodway}} [[File:2005 Winnipeg Flood.JPG|thumb|[[The Forks, Winnipeg|The Forks]] during the 2005 flood]] Because of its flat topography and substantial snowfall, Winnipeg is subject to severe flooding. The [[Red River of the North|Red River]] reached its greatest flood height in 1826, and this event still remains the highest flood stage of the last two hundred years.
[[File:Red River Floodway from the air.JPG|thumb|left|[[Red River Floodway]] from the air]] A major flood in 1950 caused a State of Emergency to be declared and the Canadian Army was brought in to protect residents and property. Because of the flood, 100,000 residents were evacuated from their homes and approximately 10,000 homes were destroyed, along with many hospitals, schools and businesses. The flood prompted the [[Politics of Manitoba|Government of Manitoba]], under former [[Premier of Manitoba|Premier]] [[Dufferin Roblin]], to build the [[Red River Floodway]]. The floodway is colloquially referred to as Duff's Ditch, and is a {{convert|47|km|abbr=on|0}} long diversion channel that protects Winnipeg from flooding.<ref name=DuffsDitch/>
Construction on the floodway project began 6 October 1962 and cost $63 million. The project resulted in excavation of approximately 76.5 million cubic metres of earth. Completed in March 1968, it has successfully prevented over $10 billion in flood damages.<ref name=DuffsDitch>{{cite web|title=Duff’s Ditch|url=http://www.floodwayauthority.mb.ca/duffsditch_history.html|publisher=Province of Manitoba Floodway Authority|accessdate=7 November 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120622160804/http://www.floodwayauthority.mb.ca/duffsditch_history.html|archivedate=22 June 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The [[flood control]] system prevented flooding in 1974 and 1979 when water levels neared record levels. However, in the [[1997 Red River Flood]], water threatened the city's relatively unprotected southwest corner. Flood control dikes were reinforced and raised using sandbags and the threat was averted. Winnipeg suffered limited damage compared to cities without flood control structures, such as [[Grand Forks, North Dakota]].
Other related [[Interbasin water diversion|water diversion]] projects farther away from Winnipeg include the [[Portage Diversion]] (also known as the Assiniboine River Floodway) and the [[Shellmouth Reservoir]].
==Flora and fauna== [[File:Horned1b.jpg|thumb|200px| The great horned owl can be found in Winnipeg.]]
Winnipeg is situated where [[tall grass prairie]] meets [[aspen parkland]] and is not very far from boreal coniferous forests of the rocky [[Canadian Shield]]. The tall grass prairie areas are notable for its endangered [[Platanthera praeclara|western prairie fringed orchid]].<ref>{{vcite web|url=http://www.cosewic.gc.ca/eng/sct1/searchdetail_e.cfm?id=200&StartRow=1&boxStatus=All&boxTaxonomic=All&location=All&change=All&board=All&commonName=orchid&scienceName=&returnFlag=0&Page=1 |title=Fringed-orchid, Western Prairie |publisher=Committee on the Status of Endangered Wildlife in Canada |accessdate=7 November 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706183933/http://www.cosewic.gc.ca/eng/sct1/searchdetail_e.cfm?id=200&StartRow=1&boxStatus=All&boxTaxonomic=All&location=All&change=All&board=All&commonName=orchid&scienceName=&returnFlag=0&Page=1 |archivedate=6 July 2011 |df=dmy }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | author = Goedeke, T | author2 = Sharma, J | author3 = Delphey, P | author4 = Marshall Mattson, K | title = ''Platanthera praeclara'' | journal = [[The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]] | volume = 2008 | page = e.T132834A3464336 | publisher = [[IUCN]] | date = 2008 | url = http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/132834/0 | doi = 10.2305/IUCN.UK.2008.RLTS.T132834A3464336.en | access-date = 12 January 2018}}</ref> Some prairie grasses include big bluestem and spear grasses; and wildflowers include aster, goldenrod, prairie crocus and lady's-slipper.<ref name="winnipeg.ca">{{vcite web |url=http://www.winnipeg.ca/publicworks/naturalist/ns/natureareas/Background.asp |title=Background (Natural History Perspective of Winnipeg) |publisher=City of Winnipeg |accessdate=7 January 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120306074227/http://www.winnipeg.ca/publicworks/naturalist/ns/natureareas/Background.asp |archivedate=6 March 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref> Some birds found around Winnipeg include [[Ferruginous hawk|ferruginous]] and [[Swainson's hawk|Swainson's]] hawks; [[Screech owl|screech]] and [[great horned owl|great horned]] owls; as well as [[Canada geese]] and [[mallard]]s.<ref name="winnipeg.ca"/> Winnipeg is also home of the largest remaining mature urban elm forest in North America.<ref name="docs.google.com">{{vcite web|url=https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:U7AAwQdD5RsJ:www.winnipeg.ca/publicworks/Forestry/PAMPHLETS/wpgtreefctspamph.doc+winnipegs+urban+forest&hl=en&gl=ca&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEESj6twoB9j5pr8LCy-B5at1q3SiNAAg3nB_XX31xYZCcHrUfmlanQ03gMs6lnkSC7xZnc0Q6v6erQz-u9v3Pxd-67LPq7TMIT99mtEJemLGXvO1-0w3otcMT24ef19gHiGsBAcQ8&sig=AHIEtbR4jcb55tkJJWpWhIYoRkD1a0qYaQ|title=WINNIPEG TREE FACTS|publisher=City of Winnipeg|accessdate=7 January 2013}}</ref> Some species of Winnipeg's 8 million trees include elm, ash, maple, oak, poplar, basswood, willow, birch, spruce, pine, cedar, as well as some fruit trees and shrubs.<ref name="docs.google.com"/> The [[Red River of the North|Red River]] is the home of a number of species of fish including [[catfish]], [[goldeye]], and [[walleye]].
==Location==
{{Canadian City Geographic Location (8-way) | Centre = Winnipeg | Northwest = [[Rockwood, Manitoba|Rockwood]]<br />[[Rosser, Manitoba|Rosser]]<br />[[St. François Xavier, Manitoba|St. François Xavier]] | North = [[St. Andrews, Manitoba|St. Andrews]]<br />[[West St. Paul, Manitoba|West St. Paul]] | Northeast = [[St. Clements, Manitoba|St. Clements]]<br />[[East St. Paul, Manitoba|East St. Paul]] | East = [[Rural Municipality of Springfield|Springfield]] | Southeast = [[Taché, Manitoba|Taché]] | South = [[Ritchot, Manitoba|Ritchot]] | Southwest = [[Macdonald, Manitoba|Macdonald]] | West = [[Rural Municipality of Cartier|Cartier]] [[Headingley, Manitoba|Headingley]] }}

revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{Orphan|date=September 2017}} {{COI|date=April 2010}} }}
The '''Global Planners Network''' (commonly abbreviated to GPN) is a group of [[spatial planning]] institutes and other organisations, who have signed the [[Vancouver Declaration]].<ref>Vancouver Declaration: http://www.globalplannersnetwork.org/pdf/06declarationenglish.pdf</ref> Members sign this declaration to show their commitment to working "together, and with others, to tackle the challenges of rapid urbanisation, the urbanisation of poverty and the hazards posed by climate change and natural disasters." Current GPN membership extends to 25 organisations representing more than 150,000 planners.
==History== The Global Planners Network was founded in 2006 at the first World Planners Congress in [[Vancouver]], as an informal collaboration. This Congress was held on June 17 to June 20, 2006, and was hosted by the [[Canadian Institute of Planners]] and the [[Planning Institute of British Columbia]], in collaboration with the [[Commonwealth Association of Planners]]. It directly preceded and fed into the third World Urban Forum (WUF3), organised by the United Nations Human Settlements Programme ([[UN-HABITAT]]) in Vancouver and facilitated and funded by the [[Government of Canada]].
The Global Planners Network held a second Congress directly preceding the fourth session of the World Urban Forum (WUF4) in [[Nanjing]], China 2008, in nearby [[Zhenjiang]]. The Congress was organised by the [[American Planning Association]] and the Zhenjiang Municipal People's Government.<ref>Zhenjiang Municipal People's Government: http://www.zhenjiang.gov.cn</ref>
The Global Planners Network founder members attended WUF4, which was hosted by the UN-HABITAT, and the [[Ministry of Housing and Urban-Rural Development]], PRC. At a WUF4 UN-Habitat Seminar ‘Global Planners Network Messages & Outreach’<ref>UN-HABITAT Seminar http://www.unhabitat.org/content.asp?typeid=19&catid=535&cid=5933#55</ref> the GPN presented its Communiqué<ref>Communiqué: http://www.globalplannersnetwork.org/pdf/08gpncommunique.pdf</ref> and latest Action Plan.<ref>Action Plan: http://www.globalplannersnetwork.org/pdf/08closingplenarymemo.pdf</ref>
==Mission & Priorities== The Global Planners Network mission was first set out at the first Global Planners Congress World Planners Congress 2006, in the Vancouver Declaration.<ref>As point 1 above - Vancouver Declaration</ref> The objectives in this Declaration were shaped by discussions at the Congress and a position paper <ref>Reinventing Planning: www.rtpi.org.uk/download/5176/reinventingplanning.pdf</ref> on what was termed "new urban planning." At the second Global Planners Congress, held in Zhenjiang from 31 October to 2 November 2008, the commitment was engraved in a commemorative stone at the Congress venue:
''"Building on the 2006 Vancouver Declaration, the Global Planners Network steers towards harmonious settlements, places in harmony with nature and places where there is harmony between people. We champion planning as a strategic, integrative, inclusive and pro-poor process. As a tool for urban development and environmental management, effective planning alleviates poverty, reduces inequality, slows down slum formation, mitigates hazards and builds safe, inclusive settlements. We leave Zhenjiang renewing our commitment to increase the global capacity to plan and manage settlements in timely, affordable and harmonious ways. We will continue to bring planners together and strengthen their links with communities, professionals, politicians and civil society to enhance the quality and future resilience of human settlements."'' Professor Stuart Emin has been made Honorary Member of the organisation.
==Members== Founder members are: [[American Planning Association]] (APA)<ref>American Planning Association (APA) http://www.planning.org</ref> [[Canadian Institute of Planners]] (CIP)<ref>Canadian Institute of Planners (CIP): http://www.cip-icu.ca</ref> [[Commonwealth Association of Planners]] (CAP)<ref>Commonwealth Association of Planners (CAP): http://www.commonwealth-planners.org</ref> Planning Institute of Australia (PIA)<ref>Planning Institute of Australia (PIA): http://www.planning.org.au</ref> [[Royal Town Planning Institute]] (RTPI)<ref>Royal Town Planning Institute (RTPI): http://www.rtpi.org.uk</ref>
In addition to the founder members, plus UN-HABITAT, the following organisations have joined the Global Planners Network: *Bangladesh Institute of Planners *Barbados Town and Country Planning Society *Ghana Institute of Planners *Hungarian Society of Urban Planning *Institute of Town Planners Sri Lanka *Irish Planning Institute *Jamaican Institute of Planners *Kenya Association of Planners *L’Association des Urbanistes de Côte d'Ivoire *L’Association des Urbanistes du Bénin *L’Association des Urbanistes du Togo *L’Association des Urbanistes et des Aménageurs algériens *L’Association Tunisienne des Urbanistes *L’Ordre National des Urbanistes du Cameroun *La Société Française des Urbanistes *Malaysia Institute of Planners *Nigerian Institute of Planners *Singapore Institute of Planners *South African Planning Institute<ref>South African Planning Institute: http://www.sapi.org.za</ref> *Uganda Institute of Physical Planners<ref>Uganda Institute of Physical Planners: http://www.uipp.ug</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
[[Category:Urban planning organizations]] [[Category:2006 establishments in Canada]]

{{Infobox settlement <!-- See Template:Infobox settlement for additional fields and descriptions --> | name = Guting | official_name = Guting District | native_name = {{nobold|{{lang|zh-hant|古亭區}}}} | native_name_lang = <!-- ISO 639-2 code e.g. "fr" for French. If more than one, use {{lang}} instead --> | other_name = | settlement_type = [[District (Taiwan)|District]]<!-- such as Town, Village, City, Borough etc. --> | translit_lang1 = | translit_lang1_type = | translit_lang1_info = | image_skyline = Guting Station Exit6.JPG | imagesize = | image_alt = | image_caption = Guting MRT Station, Today | image_map = | mapsize = | map_alt = | map_caption = Xinyi District in Taipei City | subdivision_type = Country | subdivision_name = [[Republic of China]] ([[Taiwan]]) | subdivision_type1 = Region | subdivision_name1 = Southwestern Taipei | named_for = | seat_type = <!-- defaults to: Seat --> | seat = | parts_type = Divisions | parts_style = <!-- list, coll (collapsed list), para (paragraph format) --> | parts = <!-- parts text, or header for parts list --> | p1 = 54 villages | p2 = neighborhoods | government_footnotes = <!-- for references: use <ref> tags --> | government_type = | governing_body = | leader_party = | leader_title = | leader_name = <!-- add   (no-break space) to disable automatic links --> | area_footnotes = <!-- for references: use <ref> tags --> | area_total_km2 = 6.7 | area_rank = | population_footnotes = <!-- for references: use <ref> tags --> | population_total = 186,257<ref>{{cite web |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071206035557/http://www.ca.taipei.gov.tw/civil/p03_total-3.htm |title=台北市70年以後各行政區戶數、人口數 |publisher=台北市民政局 |accessdate=2008-07-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071206035557/http://www.ca.taipei.gov.tw/civil/p03_total-3.htm |archivedate=2007-12-06 }}</ref> | population_as_of = 1989 | population_rank = | population_density_km2 = auto | postal_code_type = Postal code | postal_code = 107 }}
'''Guting District''' ({{zh|c=古亭區|p=Gǔtíng Qū}}) was a [[District (Taiwan)|district]] in [[Taipei]], [[Republic of China]], located in the southwestern part of Taipei.
== History == The name “Guting” is derived from the ancient place name Ku-ting ({{lang-nan|Kóo-tîng}}).
After [[History of Taipei#Japanese rule and leadership|Taihoku City]] was established in 1920, in 1922, the [[Taiwan under Japanese rule|Japanese Colonial Government]] carried out the {{nihongo4|Correction of Villages' Name|町名改正|chōmei kaisei}}. There were 11 {{nihongo|villages|町|chō}} in the area of later Guting District: {{nihongo|Shineichō|新榮町}}, {{nihongo|Chitosechō|千歳町}}, {{nihongo|Kodamachō|兒玉町}}, {{nihongo|Sakumachō|佐久間町}}, {{nihongo|Nanmonchō|南門町}}, {{nihongo|Ryūkōchō|龍口町}}, {{nihongo|Babachō|馬場町}}, {{nihongo|Kawabatachō|川端町}}, {{nihongo|Koteichō|古亭町}}, {{nihongo|Suidōchō|水道町}} and {{nihongo|Tomitachō|富田町}}.
In 1946, the Taiwan Province Administrative Official Public Ministry ({{lang|zh|臺灣省行政長官公署}}) made those villages incorporated as Guting District.
In 1990, 16 districts in Taipei City were consolidated into the current 12 districts. Most of Guting District were merged into [[Zhongzheng District]] ({{lang|zh|中山區}}) along with [[Chengzhong District, Taipei|Chengzhong District]] ({{lang|zh|城中區}}), moreover the rest were annexed into [[Da'an District, Taipei|Daan District]] ({{lang|zh|大安區}}) and [[Wanhua District]] ({{lang|zh|萬華區}}).
== Geography == Guting District bordered Chengzhong District ({{lang|zh|城中區}}) to the north, Daan District ({{lang|zh|大安區}}) to the east, [[Shuangyuan District]] ({{lang|zh|雙園區}}) to the west and [[Longshan District, Taipei|Longshan District]] ({{lang|zh|龍山區}}) to the northwest. The [[Xindian River]] ({{lang|zh|新店溪}}) run by its south.
== Education and Medical Institutions == === Universities and Colleges === *[[National Taiwan University]] *[[National Taiwan Normal University]]
=== High School === *[[Taipei Municipal Jianguo High School|Taipei Municipal Chien Kuo High School]]
=== Medical Institutions === *[[Postal Hospital]]<ref name="postal">{{cite web|url=http://www.postal.com.tw/|website=postal.com.tw|title=郵政醫院|accessdate=2018-01-27}}</ref> *[[Women's and Children's Hospital (Taipei)|Women's and Children's Hospital (Fuyou Hospital)]]<ref name="zhTCH">[[:zh:臺北市立聯合醫院#院區|婦幼醫院]]</ref><ref name="tpech">{{cite web|url=http://www.tpech.gov.taipei/ct.asp?xItem=2009935&CtNode=43670&mp=109161|website=tpech.gov.taipei|title=臺北市立聯合醫院和平婦幼院區 ─ 沿革|accessdate=2018-01-27}}</ref> *[[Heping Hospital]]<ref name="zhTCH" /><ref name="tpech" /> *[[Tri-Service General Hospital]]
== Government Institutions == *[[Central Bank of the Republic of China (Taiwan)|Central Bank of the Republic of China]] *[[Ministry of Finance (Taiwan)|Ministry of Finance of the Republic of China]] *[[Ministry of Economic Affairs (Taiwan)|Ministry of Economic Affairs of the Republic of China]] *[[Council of Agriculture|Council of Agriculture of the Republic of China]] *[[Taiwan Tobacco and Liquor Corporation|Taiwan Tobacco and Wine Monopoly Bureau]] *[[Ministry of Labor (Taiwan)#Third Level Agencies|Bureau of Labor Insurance]]
== Places of Interest == *[[Youth Park, Taipei|Youth Park]]<ref>[[:zh:青年公園 (臺北市)|青年公園]]</ref> *[[Taipei Botanical Garden]] *[[National Museum of History]] *[[Taipei City Children's Museum of Transportation]]<ref>[[:zh:臺北市客家文化主題公園|臺北市客家文化主題公園]]</ref><ref name="thcp">{{cite web|url=https://ssl.thcp.org.tw/about/history|author=臺北市客家文化主題公園|title=歷史緣起 - 臺北市客家文化主題公園 – Historic Origins - Taipei City Hakka Cultural Park |website =ssl.thcp.org.tw|accessdate=2018-01-27}}</ref>

[[File:HermannBerghaus.jpg|thumb|Hermann Berghaus.]]
'''Hermann Berghaus''' (born [[Herford]], [[Westphalia]], 16 November 1828; died [[Gotha]], 3 December 1890) was a [[Germany|German]] [[cartographer]].
==Biography== He was a nephew of [[Heinrich Berghaus]]. During most of his life, he was cartographer in the Geographical Institute of [[Justus Perthes]] at Gotha. His best known work is a chart of the world (1863) which went through at least 11 editions. He also prepared a ''Physikalische Wandkarte von Afrika'' (''Physical wall map of Africa'', 1881). Besides this, he supervised the revision of his famous uncle's ''Physikalischer Atlas'' (1886), which project was participated in by many noted specialists.
==References== *{{Americana|wstitle=Berghaus, Hermann|year=1920}}
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Berghaus, Hermann}} [[Category:1828 births]] [[Category:1890 deaths]] [[Category:People from Herford]] [[Category:People from the Province of Westphalia]] [[Category:German cartographers]] [[Category:19th-century German people]] [[Category:19th-century cartographers]]

{{Infobox writer | name = Hugh C. Brooks | image = Hugh C. Brooks.jpg | birth_date = {{birth date|1922|06|19}} | birth_place = Seattle, WA, USA | death_date = {{death date and age|2008|10|08|1922|06|19}} | death_place = Pembroke Pines, FL, USA | occupation = Geographer | nationality = American | period = 1954 - 2008 | subject = Economic Geography, African History }}
'''Hugh C. Brooks''' (June 19, 1922{{snd}}October 8, 2008) was an American [[Economic geography|economic geographer]], author, educator, and [[historian]] who specialized in the history and political economy of Africa.
==Life and career== Hugh Campbell Brooks was born in Seattle, Washington, on June 19, 1922. He served in the U.S. Army (1941-1946), where he was a member of Regimental HQ Company, 310th Infantry, 78th Division, and received the [[Bronze Star]], [[Purple Heart]], and [[Silver Star]] for his service in the European Theater.<ref name="auto1">"Hugh C. Brooks," ''Contemporary Authors Online''.</ref><ref>[https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/91478869&ref=acom "PFC Hugh C Brooks," ''Find A Grave'' website].</ref> He attended the [[University of Washington]] in Seattle, where he received the B.A. in 1947, and then the M.A. from the [[Graduate Institute of International and Development Studies|lnstitute of International Relations]] in Geneva in 1948. Brooks began teaching Geography at [[Oregon State University]] in Corvallis (1950-1951), and then taught at [[Teachers College]], [[Columbia University]], where he received the M.A. (1952) and Ed.D. (1954). His dissertation topic was "Directed Studies in Introductory College Geography." He also taught at [[Hunter College]], 1952-1954.<ref name="auto1"/>
A [[Fulbright Program|Fulbright award]] enabled Brooks to lecture at the [[University of the Witwatersrand]] in [[Johannesburg]], [[South Africa]] from 1955-1957, where he worked under Dr. John Wellington, before he began teaching at [[Kean University|Newark State College]] as an Associate Professor of Geography, 1957-1961.<ref>[http://digitalmemory.stjohns.edu/cdm/compoundobject/collection/alumnews1960/id/94/rec/7 "University Establishes African Institute: Brooks Named Director,"] ''St. John's University Alumni News'', Vol. 3, no. 3 (Nov. 1961): 3.</ref> Brooks then joined the faculty of [[St. John's University (New York City)|St. John's University]] in 1961 as Associate Professor of Geography and Director of their Institute of African Studies, to "prepare students to work in Africa, or for organizations working within the continent.<ref>[http://digitalmemory.stjohns.edu/cdm/compoundobject/collection/redman/id/1129/rec/2 Brooks, Hugh C. "The African Institute,"] ''Redman: St. John's University Alumni Magazine'', Vol. 10, no. 2 (Winter 1961-62): 11-13.</ref> When the African Center was discontinued, Brooks was made a member of the History Department, where he remained until his retirement, and was the Department Chair in the 1980s.<ref name="auto1"/> Brooks was elected as a Fellow of the [[Royal Geographical Society|Royal Geographical Society (London)]] in 1965.<ref>[http://digitalmemory.stjohns.edu/cdm/singleitem/collection/humanitas/id/14 "News from the Institutes,"] ''The St. John's University Humanities Newsletter'', Vol. 1, no. 3 (Spring 1965): 3.</ref>
Brooks' first wife, Savina Vicini, died in 1994. They had two children, Robert and Alison. (Robert "Bobby" Brooks was an entertainment agent who died in the same helicopter crash with [[Stevie Ray Vaughan#Death|Stevie Ray Vaughan]].)<ref>[http://articles.latimes.com/1990-08-29/news/mn-212_1_bobby-brooks-service "Bobby Brooks Service to Be Held Thursday,"] ''Los Angeles Times,'' Aug. 29, 1990.</ref> Brooks then married Beatrice Shelley and lived in Pembroke Pines, Florida, until his death in 2008.<ref name="auto1"/><ref>[http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/nytimes/obituary.aspx?n=hugh-campbell-brooks&pid=118682334 "Obituary of Hugh Campbell Brooks,"] ''New York Times'', Oct. 11, 2008.</ref>
==Scholarship== Brooks co-authored a textbook (with George T. Renner), ''Directed Studies in Introductory College Geography'' (1958), as well as (with Bertrand P. Boucher) ''Field Trips in New Jersey'' (1962), and (with Richard Keppel) ''Effective Teaching With Aero-View Transparencies: A Comprehensive Visual Presentation of the Geography, History and Economic Assets of the United States of America'' (1964). While consulting with McGraw-Hill, Sadlier, and Grolier in the late 1960s, he developed several textbooks for younger students, including ''Africa: A High School Geography'' (1966), ''Africa: A Junior High School Geography'' (1966), and ''The Old World: Africa'' (1968). He co-authored several books on African geography and culture: (with Michael G. Mensoian) ''Arab World, New Africa'' (1969); (with [[Yosef Ben-Jochannan|Yosef ben-Jochannan]] and Kempton Webb) ''Africa: Lands, Peoples, and Cultures of the World'' (1969); and (with William Norris, and David Dicker) ''The People of New Africa'' (1972).<ref name="auto1"/>
Brooks also produced three books with colleagues from St. John's: (co-editor with Yassin El-Ayouty) ''Refugees South of the Sahara: An African Dilemma'' (1970); (co-editor with Yassin El-Ayouty) ''Africa and International Organization'' (1974); and (with Francis A. Lees) ''The Economic and Political Development of the Sudan'' (1977). He also contributed articles on seven African countries to Grolier's ''Lands and Peoples'' reference set, which was first published in 1972 but subsequently went through over ten editions. Brooks worked with the Image Bank in the late 1980s to select photographs for a projected coffee-table book, ''Africa: The Land and the People'', but it was never published.<ref name="auto1"/>
==Bibliography== *[http://articles.latimes.com/1990-08-29/news/mn-212_1_bobby-brooks-service "Bobby Brooks Service to Be Held Thursday,"] ''Los Angeles Times,'' Aug. 29, 1990. *[https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/91478869&ref=acom "PFC Hugh C Brooks," ''Find A Grave'' website], 19 Dec. 2014. *"Hugh C. Brooks," ''Contemporary Authors Online'', Detroit: Gale, 2001, ''Literature Resource Center'', Web. 19 Dec. 2014. *[http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/nytimes/obituary.aspx?n=hugh-campbell-brooks&pid=118682334 "Obituary of Hugh Campbell Brooks,"] ''New York Times'', Oct. 11, 2008.

{{main|ISO 3166-2}} '''ISO 3166-2:BL''' is the entry for [[Saint Barthélemy]] in [[ISO 3166-2]], part of the [[ISO 3166]] [[standardization|standard]] published by the [[International Organization for Standardization]] (ISO), which defines [[code]]s for the names of the principal [[country subdivision|subdivision]]s (e.g., [[province]]s or [[state (administrative division)|state]]s) of all [[country|countries]] coded in [[ISO 3166-1]]. Currently no ISO 3166-2 codes are defined in the entry for Saint Barthélemy. The territory has no defined subdivisions. Saint Barthélemy, an [[overseas territories of France|overseas territorial collectivity]] of [[France]], is officially assigned the [[ISO 3166-1 alpha-2]] code {{mono|BL}} since 2007, after its secession from [[Guadeloupe]]. Moreover, it is also assigned the ISO 3166-2 code {{mono|FR-BL}} under the [[ISO 3166-2:FR|entry for France]]. ==Changes== The following changes to the entry have been announced in newsletters by the ISO 3166/MA since the first publication of ISO 3166-2 in 1998: {| class="wikitable" |- ! Newsletter ! Date issued ! Description of change in newsletter |- | id="I-9" | [http://www.iso.org/iso/newsletter_i-9.pdf {{nowrap|Newsletter I-9}}] | {{nowrap|2007-11-28}} | Addition of new entry
''(in accordance with [[ISO 3166-1#VI-1|ISO 3166-1 Newsletter VI-1]])'' |} ==External links== * [https://www.iso.org/obp/ui/#iso:code:3166:BL ISO Online Browsing Platform: BL] * [http://www.statoids.com/ubl.html Saint Barthélemy], Statoids.com {{ISO 3166}} [[Category:ISO 3166|2:BL]] [[Category:Geography of Saint Barthélemy]]
